Au and Pt nanoparticle supported catalysts tailored for H2 production: From models to powder catalysts Thuy-Duong Nguyen-Phan a ⁎ Ashleigh E. Baber b José A. Rodriguez a c Sanjaya D. Senanayake a ⁎ a Chemistry Department, Brookhaven National Laboratory, Upton, NY 11973, United States Chemistry Department Brookhaven National Laboratory Upton NY 11973 United States b Department of Chemistry and Biochemistry, James Madison University, Harrisonburg, VA 22807, United States Department of Chemistry and Biochemistry James Madison University Harrisonburg VA 22807 United States c Department of Chemistry, Stony Brook University, Stony Brook, NY 11794, United States Department of Chemistry Stony Brook University Stony Brook NY 11794 United States ⁎ Corresponding authors. Graphical abstract The use of metal nanoparticles (NPs), including Au and Pt, supported over oxides has been pivotal, and is ever increasing in enabling catalytic reactions which target the production of hydrogen. We review here the most recent works pertaining to the fundamental understanding of the structure, morphology, growth, characterization, and intrinsic phenomenological properties of Au- and Pt-based catalysts that influence the reactivity and selectivity to target hydrogen production. We draw on surface science and theoretical methods of model and powder catalysts using high resolution imaging, spectroscopy, scattering experiments, and theoretical studies. Based on these insights we identify key aspects of studies of supported metal nanoparticle (NP) catalysts for several reactions. The main focus of this review is on the intersection of catalytic chemistry related to the water-gas shift (WGS), oxygenate steam reforming (OSR), and solar-assisted reactions (SAR). Keywords Gold Platinum Supported catalyst Water–gas shift Steam reforming Water splitting 1 Introduction Heterogeneous catalysis makes use of a large range of noble metal-based catalysts that are essential for achieving industrially and commercially relevant applications specific to the ever emergent H2 economy. Whether in the production of H2 from reforming reactions (methane, syn gas, biofuels) or in the consumption of H2 in fuel cells, NH3 synthesis, hydrogenation, or methanation, we find Pt, Au and other noble metals used extensively as the active ingredient. As a result, the role of metals such as Pt and Au has been the intense focus of numerous scientific studies targeting the catalytic conversion of reactants directly to H2. These studies have evolved over time with the generation of many fundamental aspects specific to the structure, chemical nature, morphology, and the chemical behavior of these materials under reaction conditions, which gives rise to the tailoring of key steps in the catalytic process leading to H2. Though some features are ubiquitous to fundamental material properties of Pt or Au, it is now possible to influence or steer many reactions by the use of novel catalysts that can be designed to specifically target the most essential steps leading to conversion. Deactivation of reactions can also be carefully mitigated by ensuring that sufficient concentrations of the active agents are protected from the harsh conditions of a reaction. The water-gas shift reaction (Eq. (1)), oxygenate steam reforming (Eq. (2)), and solar-assisted reactions, including solar water splitting (Eq. (3)) and photocatalytic methanol reforming (Eq. (4)), are well established processes utilizing water in the feed to produce hydrogen-rich gas with high efficiency. Although Au- and Pt- supported oxide catalysts dramatically enhance the (photo) catalytic activity, the nature of active phase, in terms of size, geometry, electronic structure, in these metal/oxide systems, as well as the influence of metal↔support interactions are still ambiguous. In this review, we highlight the latest discoveries pertaining to these metals and discuss the importance of morphology, metal/support interactions, and redox states that distinguish Pt and Au from each other, and other metals, in the manifest of unique selectivity and activity. (1) WGS: CO+H2O→H2 +CO2 (2) OSR : C x H y O z + ( 2 x − z ) H 2 O → xCO 2 + ( y 2 + 2 x − z ) H 2 (3) SAR : H 2 O → hv H 2 + 1 2 O 2 (4) CH 3 OH + H 2 O → hv 3 H 2 + CO 2 This review is divided in two sections. The first part describes studies using model systems. Surface science and density functional theory (DFT) models can provide invaluable insights into the intrinsic phenomena that prevail during a heterogeneous catalytic process. In the fundamental investigation of Pt and Au materials numerous studies of well-defined metal surfaces (i.e. Pt(111), Au(111)) and supported metal NPs (i.e. Pt/CeOx, Pt/TiO2, Pt/CeOx/TiO2, Au/CeOx, Au/TiO2, Au/MgO) have provided ideal benchmarks for looking at individual steps that pertain to the conversion of oxygenated molecules to H2. Challenges exist in the transfer of knowledge obtained at model conditions to those applied to more complex powder catalysts under reaction conditions. However, an ever increasing range of methods and tools from in situ microscopy, spectroscopy and scattering, as well as time-dependent DFT methods can help bridge what has come to be known as the ‘materials and pressure’ gaps. The results of these studies can explain data for complex systems and help to predict and enable new directions in the design and understanding of high-surface-area powder catalysts. The second part of the review is focused on the rational design of real powder catalysts, paying particular attention to their synthesis, characterization and catalytic performance. 2 Surface science and DFT models Here we begin reviewing recent surface science investigations of Pt and Au model catalysts, paying specific attention to the growth, morphology, and oxidation state of the materials, before taking a closer look at the active site identification at the atomic level and with individual probe molecules. The use of models to interpret and unravel catalytic processes is an important strategy in reducing the complexity of high surface area powder catalysts and the multitude of cascading transformations that occur at steady state [1,2]. The ability to reduce the structural model down to the atomic level detail and mechanisms down to individual chemical activation steps is insightful and also critical. The use of single crystal and thin film substrates has been particularly versatile as benchmarks in these studies that can extend to mono-metals [3–6], bi and tri-metallic [7–9], oxides [10–12], mixed oxides [13–15], inverse catalysts [16–19], carbides [20–25], sulphides [21,26–28] and nitride [20,22,29,30] based catalysts. One of the most extensively studied systems is the ceria-based model, a catalytic powerhouse material, where the bulk, nano, and supported nature of a very commonly used support can readily be investigated. To mimic ceria substrates, ceria films are grown on metals in UHV. The deposition of cerium in an oxygen background leads to the formation of atomically flat ceria thin films on bulk single crystals. In one common procedure, ceria (6 monolayers (ML)) was vapor-deposited onto well-cleaned Ru(0001) substrates at elevated temperatures (790K) in an oxygen environment (1×10−7 mbar O2), and subsequently annealed to 980K in 4×10−7 mbar O2 [31,32]. Au or other metal NPs were then deposited at 300K in ultra-high vacuum (UHV) onto the ceria films via electron beam assisted evaporation from a W crucible or wire. On ceria, Au NPs were preferentially located in order of the following positions: terrace point defects, step edges, and finally, at high Au coverages, on flat terraces [32]. Before testing for WGS activity, the ceria-supported nanoparticles were annealed to the WGS reaction temperature after the deposition of Au at room temperature (RT) [33]. CeO2(111) [34] and Au(111) [33] are inactive toward the water–gas shift reaction while the Pt(111) surface exhibits a greater activity than the model system standard (Cu(111)), but is rapidly poisoned by carbon deposits [35]. Maximum WGS activity (20torr CO, 10torr H2O, 625K) was achieved on Pt/CeO2(111) with 0.2ML Pt coverage on ceria, which corresponds to Pt NPs <1.7nm in diameter, and <0.4nm in height [34]. The smaller Pt NPs that resulted from low coverages of Pt exhibited a lower density of states near the Fermi level for the Pt 5d states, as compared to the larger Pt coverages, which had a lower WGS activity and a density of states that appeared more metallic-like (shown in Fig. 1 ) [34]. This result indicates a decrease in activity as the Pt NPs become more bulk-like or metallic. Pt/CeO2(111) outperformed other metal/ceria WGS catalysts, including Au, Cu, and Ni [34]. While the Pt/CeO2 system was more active for the WGS than Au/CeO2, the Au system showed greater activity than Pt when the metal coverage was >0.5ML, and importantly, Au/CeO2 model catalysts are more active for hydrogen production via the WGS reaction than the industrial standard, Cu/ZnO, as depicted in Fig. 2 [33]. As shown in Fig. 1, the greatest WGS activity for Au/CeO2(111) occurred with 0.4–0.5ML of Au coverage [34]. The dispersion of Pt NPs is enhanced when ceria is partially reduced (CeO1.88(111)), due to the increase in the number of terrace oxygen defects which can act as preferential nucleation sites for NP growth [36]. In comparison with another reducible oxide TiO2, Au behaves uniquely upon interaction with the support. The growth and diffusion of Au NPs supported titania have been well-investigated in recent studies. The deposition of Au on TiO2(110) at room temperature resulted in Au island nucleation at step edges, and with increasing coverages of Au, 3D island growth occurred as indicated in scanning tunneling microscopy (STM) images in Fig. 3 [37]. Metallic NPs deposited on clean TiO2(110) at room temperature under UHV conditions are highly dispersed across terraces and step edges until exposed to an oxygen background (5×10−7 mbar) at 1000K. Upon oxidation at elevated temperatures, the particles migrated, and the sintering of the particles and the degree of diffusion were related to the binding energy of the metal particle to the substrate using DFT calculations [38]. As seen in Fig. 4 , Au atoms have the greatest mobility on TiO2(110) due to the largest average height (12.7±4.3Å) and the lowest density (3.02×1012 clusters/cm2) of their clusters compared to Pt. The DFT calculations of metal atoms on TiO2 surface demonstrate that the metal atoms bind preferentially at the oxygen vacancies where the binding of Pt is much stronger than Au, so that the growth of surface defects is crucial for nucleation of Au and Pt clusters [38,39]. Also, the calculated oxygen binding energies on (111) surfaces of Au and Pt imply the metal–titania binding energies are correctly predicted by the admetal–oxygen bond strengths. The oxidation state of the TiO2(110) substrate plays a large role in the dispersion of NPs deposited at room temperature. Upon cleaning via Ar+ sputtering and UHV-annealing cycles, the TiO2(110) surface contains oxygen vacancies and is in a reduced state. After oxidation (exposing the surface to O2), the surface contains little to no oxygen vacancies, whereas after hydration (exposure to water), the surface is hydroxylated. The degree of oxidation of the TiO2(110) substrate affects the diffusion rates for the metal particles at elevated temperatures [38]. For both Pt and Au, the particles diffused less on the oxidized TiO2 as compared to reduced TiO2, due to a larger barrier to diffusion, resulting in smaller cluster size, and a greater cluster density [38]. Interestingly, the hydroxylated surface exhibited a decreased barrier to Au diffusion on the hydrated surface as compared to the others (Fig. 5 ), as indicated by the presence of fairly large Au clusters predominately on the high-coordination step edges, rather than small, well-dispersed clusters across terraces of reduced and oxidized TiO2. Complementary DFT calculations predict the adhesion strength (and therefore the diffusion energy) of the NPs is related to the bond strength between the metal and the substrate [38,40]. These results identify that the metals interact uniquely with redox states of the support and are strong indicators of metal-support interaction. In light of the experimental and computational findings, Au NPs dispersed on reducible oxides are better catalysts than those supported on nonreducible ones since reducible oxides are more capable of forming O-rich Au-support interface where the adhesion of Au oxide (or cationic Au) and support is much stronger. Mixed oxides are a growing area of investigation with the ability to obtain new chemistries where mono-oxides were not able to achieve. To prepare mixed oxide substrates for instance in the case of CeOx/TiO2, cerium is deposited onto TiO2(110) in an O2 environment (1×10−7 torr) at 600K [41–43]. TiO2 imposes on CeO2 NPs nontypical coordination modes with a subsequent alteration in relative stability of Ce3+/Ce4+ states, resulting in remarkable catalytic activity enhancement [41,42]. Pt NPs 1–2 atoms high formed after the evaporation of metallic Pt on to the substrate at 300K [34]. The STM image in Fig. 6 shows features related to the individual counterparts of the catalyst. The position (a) represents ceria “wires” on the TiO2(110) substrate, meanwhile region (b) shows the position of Pt NPs on top of ceria and region (c) indicates Pt NPs residing directly on the TiO2(110); all of which were characterized by their respective topographic heights in the STM image. This provides a versatile and complex Pt/CeOx/TiO2 catalyst that shows good activity for the production of H2. The activity for the WGS reaction (20 torr CO and 10 torr H2O) was greatly enhanced for Pt NPs supported on titania when ceria was added to the TiO2(110) surface, as shown in the right panel of Fig. 6. The greatest activities were achieved on the catalysts containing miniscule coverage of Pt (<0.3ML) and 11% CeOx [34]. The Pt↔CeOx interactions where small Pt clusters electronically perturbed by interactions with ceria are much stronger, enabling the admetal to adsorb water and fully dissociate. The DFT calculations show that the corner atoms of Pt8 in contact with CeO2(111) surface or with Ce40O80 NP are strongly bound to oxygen sites of support with a net Pt→ceria charge transfer, therefore enhancing the ability to cleave OH bonds and eventually yielding H2 and CO2 via the WGS reaction (Fig. 7 ) [34,42,44,45]. This is not the case of the Au admetal (0.15 ML) where the catalytic activity of Au/CeOx/TiO2(110) was somewhat lower than Pt/CeOx/TiO2(110) [41,42]. The theoretical calculations indicate a very weak interaction of Au (with larger average height and diameter) with TiO2(110) and a negligible charge transfer while stronger electronic perturbation is observed for CeO2(111) support [40–42,46–48]. In addition, comparisons in the behavior of metal NPs with different supports can be studied. Among popular oxide materials, MgO is critical in the investigation of the effect of hydroxylation on the surface upon NP stabilization. Freund and coworkers investigated the structure and stability of Au NPs on MgO(001), paying particular attention to the effect of the presence of hydroxyl groups [49,50]. MgO(001) thin films (10 ML) were grown on Ag(001) substrates by depositing Mg in an O2 background (1×10−6 mbar) at 573K. In order to produce the hydroxylated MgO surface, water was dosed directly onto the surface at RT at a local pressure of 1×10−3 mbar, resulting in a hydroxyl coverage of 0.4ML. The hydroxyl groups enhances the stability of the Au NPs anchored onto the surface, due to the formation of strong Au-O interfacial bonds, thereby oxidizing Au NPs to small AuxOy aggregates and hampering diffusion and sintering of Au at elevated temperatures. Post-annealed Au NPs on MgO, on the other hand, exhibited larger particles with a smaller density, as shown in Fig. 8 . Beyond simply the morphology, the chemical nature of the as-prepared metal NPs is important. Fig. 9 shows the corresponding X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) spectra in which both MgO and the hydroxylated surface are covered by 0.4 ML Au. The Au NPs on MgO remain in their metallic state (Au 4f 7/2 peak is located at 84.0eV) in Fig. 9 a(i), whereas the Au NPs are oxidized on the hydroxylated surface (the Au peak is shifted to higher binding energies) in Figs. 9 a(ii) and 9a(iii). Fig. 9 b shows the O 1s region of the XPS spectra, indicating the presence of OH groups on the surface after the exposure to water at RT. The alteration in chemical nature of Au NPs can be attributed to chemisorption of hydroxyl groups stemming from direct interaction between water and small Au NPs and/or from spillover of hydroxyl groups from MgO support [50]. Furthermore, the reaction with common reactants can be titrated over these systems. For example, the adsorption of CO on MgO-supported Au clusters was imaged using STM and infrared-reflection-absorption spectroscopy (IRAS). The CO molecules preferentially adsorbed to the perimeter of the Au island, rather than on top of the particle, as shown in Fig. 10 [51]. Preferential binding sites of model catalysts can point to the active site of the material, and here CO is used as a probe molecule, as its adsorption and interaction with the surface is critical for the WGS reaction. Two-dimensional second derivative (d2 I/dV 2) maps correspond to the vibrational energy recorded at every point in a normal (topographic) STM image. A signal of ±45meV was monitored in order to investigate CO, as shown in Fig. 11 . Second-derivative images recorded at a voltage outside of the ±45meV optimal voltage for CO result in low-contrast images like that seen in Fig. 11 b, while the images recorded at ±45meV show high contrast at the perimeter of the Au island, where the CO is adsorbed. Herein, the preferential CO binding to Au island perimeter can be assigned to either the low-coordinated boundary atoms or edge atoms as opposed to those enclosed in the Au island plane, or due to the localized electrons transferred from MgO/Ag at island perimeter [51,52]. The experimental observation is consistent with DFT calculations [53,54] where CO absorbs with lower binding energy (0.72eV) to 3-fold coordinated edge atoms of negatively charged Au12 island on MgO/Ag(001) and the increase in CO-Au repulsion due to the charge donation from CO 5σ into Au. Understanding the vital roles of structural, geometric and electronic properties of active phase, oxide support, metal-oxide interface and their interaction on the atomic and molecular levels, associated with theoretical calculations is fundamental to our better understanding of heterogeneous surface reactions on supported catalyst. As a consequence, the nexus between surface science models and real-world supported catalysts is successfully established, hence not only providing new insights into the fascinating complex world of heterogeneous catalysis but also emerging mechanistic aspects to rationally design realistic, efficient supported catalysts. 3 Powder nanocatalysts It is worth noting that atomic views of model and real catalysts can shed more light on critical active sites for catalysis, yet these measurements are not trivial to make. The intersection of surface science with catalysis aims to close the pressure and materials gap by understanding chemistry on an atomic scale of real catalysts under reaction conditions. Numerous reports have highlighted the advances made in imaging real catalysts under high pressure conditions by means of using aberration-corrected environmental transmission electron microscopy (ETEM) [55–59]. Perimeter sites, low-coordination corner sites, cationic gold and bilayers of gold have been proposed as the active species in literature concerning gold catalysis [55,57,60–62]. Yoshida et al. [56] observed a reconstruction of the exposed Au{100} facets on CeO2 in the presence of 1 volume% CO in air environment, as seen in Fig. 12 . In the reconstructed surface, the Au atoms on the topmost surface layer form an undulating hexagonal lattice while those on the second topmost surface layer form a normal square lattice with slight distortion, allowing CO molecules to adsorb at higher surface coverages. Such in situ reconstruction accompanied with ab initio calculations is an important finding because it was though that a flat facet of a Au NP cannot accommodate CO molecules in high density [63,64] due to the intrinsic weak adsorption of CO molecules and the repulsive intermolecular interactions. A combination of transmission electron microscopy (TEM) and physical modeling was also used to gain insight on the active site on an atomic scale of supported metallic NPs, citing that the catalytic activity is dependent on metal corner atoms in a NP, as highlighted in Fig. 13 [57–59]. The most essential factor influencing the adsorption and reaction properties of Au atoms is their coordination with other atoms [65]. The number of corner atoms does not increase as the particle size increases above 1nm, indicating that the turnover rate is dependent on the number of particles rather than the size of the particles. Note that the number of particles will be maximized with smaller particles for any given gold loading. Continuing studies with Pt supported on ceria also shows the strong relationship between corner atom sites and the catalytic activity. Careful steps were taken by the Cargnello et al. [59] to monitor structural changes to the size and shape (of which there were none) of the NPs due to the deposition and calcination processes via TEM. Post-mortem TEM images revealed that minimal sintering or coalescence of the particles occurred, indicated by the lack of change in size, cubo-octahedron shape, or distribution of the particles. Ceria-supported catalysts show a relationship between NP diameter and activity, revealing the importance of the atoms, perimeter or corner atoms, at the metal-support interface, yet their model supports the theory that the corner atoms are the most catalytically active site due to their low coordination number compared to the other perimeter atoms [57–59], as shown in Fig. 14 . Such a conclusion is quite consistent with the observation from surface science models aforementioned. 3.1 Synthesis approaches of NPs supported catalysts Employing a suitable synthesis method to produce ultrafine, small Au and Pt NPs highly dispersed on the support is of the utmost importance for the high reactivity, selectivity and stability of supported catalysts. Isolated single atoms, subnano-sized metal clusters and nanosized particles have been elucidated to significantly improve the catalytic performance in different aspects: (i) strong metal-support interaction, (ii) intimate interfacial contact, (iii) quantum size effect, (iv) increased surface-to-volume ratio, (v) low-coordination environment of metal centers, and (vi) band alignment [66–70]. Almost no activity was obtained over bulk Au catalysts whereas uniformly dispersed, ultrafine Au NPs smaller than 10nm became highly active for H2 and CO oxidation as well as other reactions as proven by surface science studies. It is attributed to the electronic states of the outer surface gold atoms composed about 40% of total atom content for hemispherical Au NPs of diameter 4nm as well as the strong-metal-support interaction between Au and transition metal oxides [71,72]. Isolated Au single atoms supported on Fe2O3 are much more resistant to sintering than Au nanostructures due to the formation of strong covalent metal–support interaction, exhibiting ultra-stability and remarkable catalytic performance [72,73]. Similarly, size effect is crucial over Pt supported catalysts where isolated single Pt atoms anchored to the surfaces of Fe2O3 nanocrystallites exhibited excellent stability and high activity for CO oxidation arising from the partially vacant 5d orbitals of the positively charged, high-valent Pt atoms that help to reduce both the CO adsorption energy and the activation barriers for CO oxidation (shown in Fig. 15 ) [74,75]. Otherwise, the sintering or agglomeration of Pt and Au NPs to form larger particles via either Ostwald ripening or coalescence dramatically suppresses the overall activity or selectivity of the catalysts over a period time under catalytic reaction conditions and even during catalyst synthesis. It is noteworthy that the choice of a proper support plays a critical role in stabilizing the dispersed noble metal NPs and thus preventing such phenomena by means of the metal–support interaction and interfacial surface. Reducible oxides such as TiO2, CeO2 and Fe2O3 are considered active supports whereas non-reducible Al2O3, MgO and SiO2 are declared to be inert or passive [71,72,75–81]. Among these supports, titania and ceria are most widely used in the catalytic production of H2, particularly in the water-gas shift reaction at low temperature, oxygenate steam reforming and solar-assisted production, because of their oxygen storage capacity. The support might affect the shape of the noble metal NPs, resulting in faceting and possibly inducing defect sites [77,78,82]. The “junction effect” arising from the strong contact between support and noble metal NPs efficiently enhanced the catalytic activity since the electronic interaction between them reduced the enthalpy for oxygen vacancy formation, thus forming the catalytic active sites [83]. The metallic Au clusters in close contact with surface oxygen-vacancy defects of CeO2 and the fast Ce4+ ↔Ce3+ transfer are crucial in activity and stability improvement [78]. Similarly, the oxygen-vacancy F-center defects in or near the MgO surface plays an essential role in the activation of Au clusters by serving to anchor Au clusters and to partially transfer the electronic charge from the substrate F-center to Au cluster, therefore promoting the catalytic activity [77,79]. By contrast, the charge transfer also occurs across the interface from Au to various oxide supports, i.e. CeO2, TiO2, ZrO2, ZnO, Al2O3, to facilitate the catalysis reactions [78,80,81]. In addition, the oxidation state of active Au and Pt plays a crucial role in heterogeneous catalytic reactions. Numerous studies have pointed out the importance of metallic gold and platinum during WGS reaction [78,84–86]. Negatively charged gold sites (Auδ−) exposed at the surface of small clusters (<1nm) were observed on the freshly reduced sample and under working conditions whereas they became neutral after WGS reaction [78]. On the contrary, the activity for the low temperature water-gas shift reaction was found to arise from the oxidized metal embedded in the support as opposed to the metallic NPs supported on the ceria [60]. Gold cations are keys for an active catalyst where the oxidized gold species, Aun δ+, showed much lower activity for low temperature CO oxidation than that of well dispersed Au0 NPs, while oxidized gold clusters were needed to activate the WGS reaction due to the formation of active oxidized [Aun-O-Ce] and [Aun-O-Fe] species on the surface and subsurface layers of the catalysts [81]. The isolated surface-type Au3+ ions are the most active sites not only for the WGS reaction but also for the hydrogenation of 1,3-butadiene and ethylene irrespective of supports due to their ability to activate carbon–carbon double and triple bonds [87–89]. The catalytic activity was also reported to be enhanced for alkali-promoted oxidized Pt atoms complexed with OH groups on alumina, silica and titania supports [90,91]. The atomically dispersed Pt-alkali-Ox(OH)y species are explored to be the active sites, opening a new low-temperature reaction pathway. Similarly, stabilization of atomic, oxidized Au-O(OH)x by alkali ions also catalyzes the low-temperature WGS reaction, and the activity is unaffected by the nature (i.e. the reducibility) of the support [92,93]. It is obvious that the nature of Pt and Au NPs, including the composition (mono- or bimetallic), particle size, geometry, dispersity and electronic environment, on the support plays an essential role in the structure-activity correlation, product selectivity and catalyst stability arising from the metal-oxide interaction as well as the alteration in electronic configuration. Reducible and non-reducible oxides, such as SiO2, TiO2, CeO2, Fe2O3, ZrO2, Al2O3, MgO, and mixed metal oxides have been widely used as supports due to theirs high specific surface areas, high thermal and mechanical stability, and earth-abundance [72,75,77,78,80,81,94]. The preparation method has been reported to significantly affect the performance of Pt- and Au-based catalysts [95–97]. Accordingly, the gold-based catalysts are only active when in a highly dispersed state whereas the pretreatment of Pt-based catalysts is an important factor. The loading of Pt, Au, and Pt-Au alloys on various supports have been conducted by several methods including impregnation, deposition-precipitation, wet chemical reduction, photoreduction and polyol-assisted process. Chloroauric acid, gold chloride, gold acetylacetonate, nitrato (triphenylphosphine) gold (I), hexachloroplatinic acid, tetrammonium nitrate platinate, and platinum acetylacetonate are commonly used as metal precursors. The impregnation techniques, including wetness impregnation [75,98–112] and incipient wetness impregnation (or dry impregnation) followed by drying are the most commonly used methods due to their simplicity and low waste streams [60,113–116]. The precious metal ions can be reduced to their metallic state by post-treatment in different atmospheres. However, large particle sizes (8–20nm) result from sintering due to the weak interaction between the NPs and the support. Otherwise, deposition-precipitation (DP) is considered as one of the most successful techniques [64,65,78,96] to deposit highly dispersed, catalytically active noble metal NPs (NPs), particularly Au, on metal oxides with an isoelectric point (IEP) above 5 (IEPTiO2 =6–6.5, IEPCeO2 =6.7–8.6, IEPγ-Al2O3 =7–8, IEPMgO =9.8–12.7, IEPα-Fe2O3 =8.4–8.5). The precipitation method follows the principles of nucleation and growth using aqueous sodium hydroxide, ammonia, urea, and sodium carbonate as precipitating agents (shown in Fig. 16 ) [56,57,64,65,73,80,81,96,97,117–126]. The gradual decomposition of urea or ammonia during the process results in a slower, more homogeneous precipitation, therefore minimizing the aggregation of precipitates and the loss of noble metal. The gold uptake during precipitation strongly depends on pH, temperature and specific surface area of the support. The deposition at a pH above the IEP of the support involves an increasingly negative charge of the support, inducing an electrostatic repulsion of gold-containing anions, thereby limiting the deposition of Au on the solid [97]. Another efficient approach is wet-chemical reduction by adding a reducing agent, i.e. sodium borohydride, hydrazine, ascorbic acid, oleyamine or citrate, to the metal precursor solution [127–138]. The adsorption of noble metal ions onto the support surface followed by the reduction induces highly dispersed metal NPs (Au, Pt, Au-Pt alloy) in intimate contact with the support [130,131,134,135]. Naldoni et al. [134] loaded Au and Pt NPs (3-4nm) well dispersed on core (highly defective)-shell (stoichiometric) black TiO2 (80% anatase −20% rutile) nanocrystals by using aqueous sodium borohydride solution as reducing agent. Similarly, uniform dispersion of fine Au, Pt and Au-Pt alloyed NPs (2–3nm) with 1wt% of total metal content onto active TiO2 was prepared by Wang et al. [135]. The formation of homogeneous alloyed-structure in the Au-Pt solid solution was obtained in which Pt metal, with a low heat of surface energy compared to Au, has a tendency to accumulate on the surface, inducing the Au@Pt core@shell structure. Several studies have reported the combinations of impregnation and reduction method, deposition-precipitation and reduction methods as well as reduction and impregnation methods to further control the size and shape of noble metal NPs [77,81,121,130,136–138]. For example, Naldoni et al. [131] combined the wetness impregnation and reduction by NaBH4 to homogeneously grow spherical Au (3.6nm) and Pt (2.9nm) NPs over the whole TiO2 surface with a narrow size distribution. On the other hand, the polyol process using ethylene glycol solution of the metal precursor has been employed extensively to produce metal NPs supported on different oxides [139–141]. Such glycolate-metal complexes are decomposed by reflux or microwave radiation to yield in situ generated reducing species to produce colloidal metals which are subsequently captured by a support material suspended in the solution. Photoreduction or in situ photodeposition is also an appropriate and convenient process for the deposition of Au and Pt onto the surface of semiconductor support, particularly TiO2, through the generation of electron/hole pairs by UV irradiation that simultaneously oxidizes the sacrificial solvent or organic compound in the solution (i.e. alcohol, oxalic acid, glacial acetic acid) and reduces noble metal NPs [142–149]. Apart from the methods aforementioned, the deposition of Au and Pt has been conducted by other techniques such as flame spray pyrolysis, galvanic replacement, sonochemical method, microemulsion technique, direct ionic exchange and solution combustion method (Fig. 17 ) [65,137,150–153]. 3.2 Structure-reactivity correlation and mechanistic insights 3.2.1 Water–gas shift reaction The catalytic WGS reaction is one of the most important industrial processes to produce clean hydrogen. Among several classes of catalysts, noble-metal-support oxide catalysts, particularly Pt and Au based ones, are commonly studied. Burch [85] overviewed the advantages and drawbacks of gold catalysts by comparing that of platinum catalysts for the WGS reaction. Gold catalysts can offer some advantages in the low-temperature range (180–250°C) where the platinum analogs are insufficiently active; and by contrast, the properly activated platinum catalysts exhibits much higher activity than that of gold at higher temperatures. Jacobs et al. [113,120] have reported that it required approximately 20-times more of a 5% Au/CeO2 catalyst to produce the same lightoff curve as found for a 5% Pt/CeO2. Au reduction in H2 was significantly hindered at low loadings where metal-support interaction between Au and ceria were the greatest. Similar behavior was observed in the study from Si et al. [124] where the strong interaction between Au and ceria-titania support efficiently prevented the massive agglomeration of Au NPs from sintering, resulting in only ∼15% drop of conversion after 20h under WGS conditions. Temperature-programmed reduction (TPR), in situ X-ray absorption near edge structure (XANES) and in situ diffuse reflectance infrared Fourier transform spectroscopy (DRIFTS) studies showed that the extent of ceria reduction at lower temperatures over Pt catalyst was higher and deeper than in the case of Au, facilitating the formation of germinal OH groups (serving as the active sites) on the surface of ceria and therefore, yielding higher formate concentrations upon the addition of CO (as shown in Fig. 18 ). They concluded that one should not select a Pt catalyst with a low Pt loading and test it in a low temperature shift range where the catalyst is not in an active state [113,120]. It is noteworthy that the enhanced activity of CeO2 supported noble metal catalysts is frequently ascribed to the ability of ceria to undergo fast storage/release of oxygen cycles via a reversible conversion between Ce4+ and Ce3+ oxidation species [154]. These redox cycles imply a mechanism of oxygen vacancy formation that is indirectly correlated with the catalyst ability to activate oxygen species through electronic transfer and thus, to the catalytic activity in oxidation reactions. Apart from stabilizing small Au NPs, the presence of Ce3+ facilitated the dissociation of water during the WGS reaction that happens at the surface of oxide support or at the interface of oxide-gold [78,124,155]. It has also been reported that Pt NPs exhibit identical function, assisting the dehydrogenation of the formate intermediate or dissociating H2O to promote the decomposition of these mobile species [109,120]. The activity comparison between monometallic Pt and Pt-alloy structures has also been investigated extensively [109,156–158]. The intimate contact between Pt and second metal drastically promotes the catalytic reactions. In comparison with Pt-CeO2 and Ru-CeO2, the Pt-Ru alloyed catalyst with a mean particle size of 2nm induced a small reduction in the intrinsic catalytic activity; meanwhile the alloyed structure was beneficial to the overall selectivity toward WGS reaction due to the prevention of CO bond cleavage and subsequent hydrogenation of C to methane (Fig. 19 ) [109]. Such alloying substantially inhibited the formation of gaseous methane and metal-bound formate species on the surface without diminishing the WGS activity or impacting the apparent activation energy. Castaño et al. [111] have evaluated the supports (γ-Al2O3, CeO2/γ-Al2O3, Ce0.8Fe0.2/γ-Al2O3), the nature of the metal (Pt, Au), the dispersion, and the stream composition to find they each directly influence the WGS performance due to their modification of the materials' electronic properties. Stronger metal-support contact between NPs (Au or Pt) and CeO2 and Ce-Fe solid solution has been elucidated, in comparison with weaker interaction between γ-Al2O3 support and NPs, via: (i) the rearrangement of band gap structure due to the formation of partially reduced ceria (Ce3+ ions) and oxygen vacancies, and the presence of metal induced gap states; (ii) the broadening and shifting of the F2g Raman signal to lower wavenumbers; and (iii) local morphology of Au and Pt NPs on Ce0.8Fe0.2/γ-Al2O3 where Pt atoms sit on oxygen vacancies and the partially filled f states of Ce3+ act as donors and 5d states of Pt as acceptor levels [111,154,155,158,159]. They also stated that at low temperature, gold catalysts are always more active than the corresponding platinum catalysts, but the reverse is true for temperatures above 200°C [111]. It is very important that the solid solution support not only facilitates the electron transfer but also increases the number of oxygen vacancies, hence promoting the redox WGS mechanism [154]. Furthermore, Acerbi et al. [160] rationalized the electronic interactions at the interface occurring in noble metal/ceria/alumina systems (Pt, Pd, Rh, Ru, Ag, Au) using Nørskov’s d-band center theory [161]. As shown in Fig. 20 , an inverse “volcano” type correlation between the d-band centers of noble metals and the enhancement in ceria reducibility was found. They suggested that the d-band center is a more effective electronic descriptor of the noble metal than the work function since it takes into account how the H2 chemisorption is affected by the metal structure. Although the promoted reduction of surface ceria reduction is limited by H2 dissociation on Au NPs and Pt to ceria reduction is limited by its affinity to O2 as a non-dissociative reducing agent was used (i.e. CO in the WGS stream), both Au and Pt NPs could allow a promoted ceria reduction at lower temperatures. The differences in activity between Au and Pt catalysts may be explained by different reaction pathways where the adsorption/activation of CO, the creation of oxygen vacancies at the metal-support interface and the water dissociation are crucial [109,124,126,162–164]. As mentioned above, numerous reports have found that nonmetallic or oxidized Pt and Au species in nanosized support can play the role of active sites for WGS activity whereas Pt or Au NPs are spectator species [60,81,90–93,109,114]. Ionic states of Au (+1, +3) and Pt (+2, +4) co-exist in clusters of atoms in which Aun-O-Ce, Ptn-O-Ce structures and surface Pt-O phases strongly bound to ceria support are stable after 15h of WGS condition [60]. As a result, Au increases the concentration of reactive surface oxygen in ceria which occurs through partial lattice filling of vacant Ce sites with Ptδ+ or Auδ+, creating additional oxygen vacancies on the surface of Ce4+-O2 fluorite-like structure. Thus, the chemistry takes place on these atomically dispersed oxidized species and involves the neighboring OH groups. Otherwise, in situ Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy (FTIR) study elucidated that the WGS reaction sites appear to be the sites at the boundary of very small Au clusters (<1nm) highly dispersed at the surface of defective ceria (CeO2−x) [78]. The active sites could be located only on the supported Au NPs or on the perimeter of gold-oxide interface [82,84,86]. CO is mainly adsorbed on Auδ− sites initially, and these Au clusters become Au0 and partially Auδ+ in the presence of water as a consequence of water dissociation on ceria defects [78,86]. However, in situ time-resolved X-ray absorption spectroscopy (TR-XAS) and in situ time-resolved X-ray diffraction (TR-XRD) indicate that cationic Auδ+ species cannot be the key sites responsible for WGS activity in spite of Au0 and Au3+ states in as-prepared catalyst [84]. The full reduction of gold oxide at the Au-CeO2 interface and partial reduction of ceria support occur simultaneously under reaction condition, leading to the disappearance of Auδ+ and the generation of Ce3+ and oxygen vacancies. 3.2.2 Oxygenate steam reforming reaction The use of oxygenated hydrocarbons or biofuels (i.e. ethanol, methanol, biomethanol, n-butanol, glycerol) for hydrogen production by steam reforming has been a great advantage over other processes due to the neutral of CO2—a greenhouse gas that causes the global warming. Steam reforming (SR) of oxygenated hydrocarbons is thermodynamically favorable at lower temperatures than non-oxygenated hydrocarbons because it is more exothermic [165–169]. In order to maximize the H2 production, the formation of byproducts and carbon accumulation must be minimized during the SR reaction. Several materials comprised of non-noble metal and noble metal supported catalysts have been developed for such a reaction and it is noteworthy that the nature of both the metal and the support is a key factor to enhance the catalytic performance of SR catalysts [98–102,104–106,108,115,116,128,165–173]. Noble metals, particularly Pt, as active phases deposited on metal oxide or mixed metal oxide supports have been widely studied [98–100,115,116,170–173]. Duan and Senkan [102] prepared libraries of catalytic materials comprised γ-Al2O3, SiO2, TiO2, CeO2 and Y-ZrO2 pellets impregnated with 42 elements from the periodic table at 4 different loadings (0.5, 1, 2.5 and 5 wt%) for ethanol SR reaction screening. They found that Pt/TiO2 and Pt/CeO2 were the most significant new leads, exhibiting the highest ethanol conversions (+90%) and hydrogen selectivities (∼30%) at 300°C among all 840 single component catalytic materials explored. In spite of much lower surface area, the competitive performance of Pt/CeO2 compared to Pt/TiO2 could be attributed to higher oxygen storage capacity of CeO2, preserving the high dispersion of Pt during the repeated oxidation-reduction cycles. Additionally, the carbon deposition was also prevented after 5–6h duration, stabilizing their catalytic activities. However, CH4 (1.5–2%) and CO (0.5%) were also formed as byproducts over these supported Pt catalysts. Obviously, Pt promotes the reduction of ceria support, facilitating the generation of Type II bridging OH groups on ceria surface [171,173–177]. It can be ascribed to either vacancy formation, followed by dissociation of water, or by direct dissociation and spillover of hydrogen from Pt to the ceria surface. As illustrated in Fig. 21 , Jacobs and Davis [171] proposed that SR of methanol undergoes four steps: (i) dissociative adsorption of methanol to produce Type II methoxy species and adsorbed hydrogen; (ii) oxidative decomposition of methoxy groups by adsorbed water to liberate two hydrogen molecules and generate surface formate; (iii) water-assisted decomposition of formate to hydrogen and unidentate carbonate; and (iv) decomposition of carbonate to carbon dioxide. The SR of ethanol proceeds via the dehydrogenation and dehydration reactions in which the former are promoted at the metal particles and metal-support interface [105,169]. Otherwise, it has been elucidated that Pt supported Al2O3 is much more effective at converting secondary liquid products, either by decomposition or reaction, to simple gas phase components (Fig. 22 ) [116,172]. Accordingly, carbon monoxide is reacting with steam via the WGS reaction faster than it does with hydrogen via methanation, therefore reducing the carbon monoxide level but maintaining high hydrogen selectivity. The presence of coke in form of whisker carbon/carbon nanotube was observed but did not significantly deactivate under reaction conditions at 873K possibly due to a higher H:C ratio of the deposit on Pt/Al2O3 and/or the ability of ethanol to efficiently clean amorphous carbon from the surface. Comparing Pt with other noble metals, the H2 and CO selectivities for SR of ethanol followed the order: Rh>>Pt>Ru≈Pd as loaded on Al2O3 (seen in Fig. 23 ) [100]. The order of Pt>Pd>Rh>Ru was achieved from Erdőhelyi and Basagiannis’s reports [104,105] where dispersed metallic Pt exhibited much higher activity and selectivity toward H2 production and long term stability at low temperatures. On the contrary, considering both the influence of metal nature (Rh, Pt, Ni, Cu, Zn, Fe) and the role of support (γ-Al2O3, 12%CeO2-Al2O3, CeO2, Ce0.63Zr0.37O2), Auprêtre et al. [98] observed lower activities and selectivities towards CO2 using Pt/Al2O3 compared to Rh and Ni catalysts, suggesting that the most selective catalyst in SR of ethanol should contain no WGS promoters. The support may promote the migration of OH groups toward the metal particles, catalyze the reforming reaction or stabilize the metals at high temperatures under steam [98,105]. It can be concluded that the different nature of both metal loading and oxide carrier can be drastically contributed to such differences in the catalytic performance. The addition of small amounts of Pt to Ni, Cu, or Co catalysts significantly lowers the formation of coke deposits by dehydrogenation of CxHy intermediates [178] and thus, increases the stability for the bimetallic catalysts [106,108,179–181]. Profeti et al. [115] investigated the catalytic activity of Ni/CeO2-Al2O3 catalysts promoted with noble metals (Pt, Ir, Pd and Ru) at low contents (0.3wt%) for the SR of ethanol (at 450 and 600°C) and glycerol (at 700°C). The bimetallic systems containing Pt and noble metals efficiently decreased the reduction temperature of nickel surface species interacting with the support, owing to a hydrogen spillover effect. These noble metals also stabilized the Ni sites in the reduced state along with the reforming reaction, increasing the conversion of oxygenated hydrocarbons and H2 yield, and suppressing the coke formation. Furthermore, the interaction between Ni and noble metal NPs may alter the electronic structure of the catalyst, arising from a shift in the d-band center that causes a change of the adsorption strength of reaction intermediates, thus facilitating the scission of CC bond. Similarly, the presence of Pt caused an increase in the exposition of Ni metal atoms on Al2O3 support (shown in Fig. 24 ) [106]. Electronic interaction between Pt and Ni active phases in the bimetallic formulation induced higher activity in the CC bond rupture of ethanol or C2 intermediate molecules, revealing better stability and superior catalytic performance in ethanol steam reforming than Ni and Pt monometallic counterparts. Ethylene hydrogenation over Pt competed with ethylene dehydrogenation over Ni particles, minimizing the coke formation; meanwhile, the higher activity of Ni in the CC bond breakage released hydrogen that allows Pt to hydrogenate the ethylene formed on Al2O3. Similarly, Ávila-Neto et al. [108] indicated that the fraction of metallic Co under reaction conditions was dependent on either the nature of the support (Al2O3, La2O3/Al2O3, CeO2/Al2O3 and CeO2/MgAl2O4) or the existence of Pt promoter. H2 was activated on metallic Pt sites in lieu of oxygen vacancies in Co oxides, generating atomic hydrogen which migrates to the surface of CoO and Co3O4 by hydrogen spillover mechanism, and thus facilitating the reduction of Con+ to Co0. Such controlling of Co2+/Co0 ratio was helpful to equilibrium the steps of ethanol activation and carbon oxidation, stabilizing the catalysts. Reversely, the steam reforming activity of Pt is strongly affected by the addition of secondary metals such as Au, Pd, Ru, In, Fe, Rh [182–185]. Pt-Fe/ZrO2 outperformed in methanol steam reforming reaction compared to other bi- and mono-metallic counterparts owing the surface segregation of Fe due to its high affinity of Fe for oxygen during calcination, leading to Pt-rich core containing ∼60% Pt0 content apart from surface Pt-oxide states like PtO and PtO2 (Fig. 25 ) [183]. However, Pt-Ru supported by γ-Al2O3 has been elucidated to be a highly efficient ethanol steam reforming catalyst [184]. Pt-Rh/CeO2 is also an active catalyst for ethanol steam reforming because very small Rh clusters efficiently dissociated the terminal CH bond and CC bond, thus increasing H2 selectivity [182]. On the other hand, the fact that Au supported oxide catalysts have been elucidated to be active for either WGS or CO oxidation at low temperature has motivated the reactivity for ethanol reaction [186–188]. By means of XPS, FT-IR, temperature programmed desorption (TPD), Idriss and coworkers [186,187] have proven that the addition of Au onto CeO2 efficiently suppressed the exclusive formation of surface acetaldehyde and acetate species as well as partially reduced CeO2 surface even at ambient conditions, hindering the capacity of support to further oxidize ethanol in stoichiometric conditions. Moreover, Au NPs stabilized ethoxide species and favored the formation of CO2 and H2. However, the DFT-computed higher dissociation barrier of the transition state for CC, CO, CH and OH bond cleavages for Au(111) (group 11) compared to Pt(111) (group 10) and other noble metals (i.e. Rh, Ir) suggests poor catalytic properties for ethanol steam reforming [189–191]. Also, much lower density of state (DOS) distribution near the Fermi level of Au(111) surface revealed relatively less active catalyst for redox reactions [190]. Considering both the computed results, (111) surface of Au is expected to be less efficient data explains in SR of ethanol, explaining why Au metal or Au supported catalyst has infrequently been reported in the hydrogen production from ethanol steam reforming [192,193]. However, Au catalysts work well in methanol steam reforming [171,194]. Taking into account the influence of the support, Pompeo et al. [75] found that the support with neutral character, like SiO2, favored the dehydrogenation and subsequent cleavage of CC bonds towards glycerol steam reforming performance, exhibiting excellent activity levels to gaseous products, high selectivity to H2, and good stability, whereas the acidity-rich supports, such as γ-Al2O3, ZrO2 and Ce4Zr1/α-Al2O3, promoted the lateral reactions of dehydration, dehydrogenation, hydrogenolysis and condensation, thus facilitating the catalyst deactivation due to coke formation and demonstrating low conversion to gaseous products (Fig. 26 ). However, Gazsi et al. [195] observed the highest activity toward methanol steam reforming over the catalyst containing Au dispersed on CeO2 support (H2 yield of ∼97%), followed by MgO and TiO2 support, and the lowest for SiO2; meanwhile using an Al2O3 support favored the dehydration reaction that yielded other products. It can be ascribed to the interface between Au NPs and partially reduced CeOx where the electronic interaction occurred between reactive Au and n-type CeO2 semiconductors. Similarly, loading platinum@zinc oxide core-shell NPs onto SiO2–Al2O3 support led to comparable methanol steam reforming activity and selectivity for CO2 as a conventional Pt/ZnO catalyst and much higher than those obtained over conventional Pt/Al2O3 and Pd-based catalysts, owing to a Pt-Zn alloy formation upon reduction due to the intimate contact between these materials [128]. 3.2.3 Solar-assisted H2 production Apart from the WGS and SR processes, H2 can be photocatalytically produced from water, wastewater or chemical compounds; and TiO2 is the most well-known photocatalyst for water splitting due to its nontoxicity, cheapness, stability, and earth-abundance. However, its wide band gap allowing the photoactivity only under UV region and the fast recombination of photoinduced electron/hole pairs significantly limits the performance of bare TiO2. The deposition of Pt and Au NPs with larger work functions (Φ) (lower Fermi level) onto the surface of TiO2 and other semiconductor oxides facilitates the efficient separation of charge carriers due to the trapping of photoinduced electrons to be involved in the reduction of hydrogen ions, the formation of a space charge layer at the metal-semiconductor interface [196], improving the charge separation and thus the photocatalytic hydrogen evolution (shown in Fig. 27 ). The greater the difference between the work function of the noble metal (ΦPt =−5.93eV, ΦAu =−5.31eV versus vacuum) [197] and of TiO2 support (ΦTiO2 =4.2eV) [198], the higher the Schottky barrier with consequent increased efficiency of photoinduced electron transfer and trapping by the metal NPs, leading to higher H2 evolution rate [137,199]. Alternatively, Joo et al. [133] proposed a new thinking about the reduction of protons on the semiconductor surface, not Au NPs. The reduced atomic hydrogen subsequently migrates to Au and recombines to yield H2 as seen in Fig. 28 . Pt has been widely employed as a co-catalyst for H2 production under UV light excitation due to its highest work function and low overpotential toward the reduction of protons to generate H2 [95,137,198,199]. However, plasmonic Au NPs not only harvest visible light and convert the photons to free energetic electrons but also promote the solar-to-hydrogen conversion by increasing the separation of electron-hole pair driven by the plasmonic resonant energy transfer (PRET) which would occur between the electromagnetic, generated by surface plasmonic resonance (SPR), and the resonant electronic levels of semiconductors [68,131–134,200]. A diagram in Fig. 29 illustrates the model of SPR-induced charge carrier formation and subsequent charge transfer mechanism [68]. Increasing Au loading on anatase TiO2 to optimal values results in the increased rate of H2 production most likely due to a geometric rather than an electronic effect, particularly, a reduction in the available metal-support sites where both metal and support are needed for the photocatalytic reaction [121,123,145]. However, the lower activity and faster deactivation in H2 production was observed on Pt-based catalysts compared to the equivalent gold catalyst due to a more rapid poisoning of the active sites which possibly stems from oxygen species strongly adsorbed on the surface of metallic NPs [107]. While Pt introduced ohmic contact, Au NPs underwent charging, storage and transport of interfacial electrons at the Au-oxide interface, inducing Fermi level equilibrium [107]. Additionally, the H2 evolution rates from aqueous ascorbic acid solution over Au/TiO2 under the light irradiation >420nm was three-times greater than Pt/TiO2 due to SPR-enhanced charge separation as shown in Fig. 30 [145]. It is worth mentioning that the size of Au contributes differently to SPR-mediated enhancement via the different absorption and scattering efficiency. The greater SPR absorption over a wider wavelength range is pronounced for larger Au particle size, resulting in larger number of absorbed photons and higher activity [201]. However, too large NP size (>40–50nm) induces much stronger radiative scattering of resonant photons than the absorption and smaller one (<20–30nm) can create the energetic charge carriers, leading to surface plasmon decay [202,203]. The electron ‘spillout’ effect can occur for Au clusters smaller than 5nm due to a reduction of average electron density [201,204]. Otherwise, larger particle size reduces the available noble metal-oxide support sites for the necessary reaction [123]. Naldoni et al. [134] studied the energy transfer mechanisms over Au and Pt loaded on core (highly defective)-shell (stoichiometric) black TiO2 nanocrystals by means of cathodoluminescence (CL) spectroscopy. Pt NPs induced a dramatic quenching of CL signals compared to black TiO2 due to the better separation of electron–hole pairs generated by the electron beam whereas in the case of Au/TiO2, the strong emission enhancement is associated with an increased density of charge carriers that recombine through radiative pathways (shown in Fig. 31 ). The deposition of Au NPs (1wt%) resulted in higher H2 production rates in the photocatalytic methanol steam reforming compared to Pt NPs due to the synergistic effect between the intragap electronic states related to abundant oxygen vacancies of black TiO2 and the interband transition of Au, and the SPR transitions under visible light as indicated in Fig. 32 . The superiority of Au-based catalysts for photocatalytic H2 production compared to Pt ones is consistent with the literature [103,123]. However, such observations are in apparent contrast with previous studies where platinum is reported as a better co-catalyst than gold [131,137]. Accordingly, the better performance of Pt/TiO2 was ascribed to the greater ability of Pt, with respect to Au, in acting as an effective electron sink, therefore limiting the electron-hole recombination to a larger extent. The more efficient the separation between photoinduced charge carriers, the more efficient are not only the conduction band electrons involved in the reduction path to produce H2, but also the valence band holes initiated complete methanol oxidation to CO2 [137]. The in situ electron spin resonance (ESR) spectroscopy demonstrated the easier electron transfer from Ti3+ to Pt, where the H+ reduction to H2 occurs, than the others under UV–vis irradiation due to less amount of Ti3+ active sites (following the order TiO2 >Au/TiO2 >>Pt/TiO2) [131]. Nevertheless, excessive Pt loading (beyond the optimal content, 0.5∼1wt%) results in the larger aggregated particles and lower dispersity on the oxide support surface. It not only shields the active surface for light activation but also becomes the recombination centers that trap photogenerated electrons, hence diminishing the charge carrier separation and decreasing the photoactivity. Recently, Wang et al. [135] have reported that the homogeneous Au@Pt core@shell structure showed a flattening of the Au SPR band in the visible light region due to the strong metal–metal interactions at the alloy interface. Au-Pt/TiO2 catalyst produced 3550μmole of H2 within 3h irradiation that is almost 2.4-, 1.7- and 9.8-fold increase compared to Au/TiO2, Pt/TiO2 and bare TiO2, respectively. Such enhancement in photocatalytic activity is attributed to stronger interaction between Au-Pt and TiO2 support, higher electron population on the alloyed structure and greatly improved photoinduced charge separation in the bimetallic system. However, Li et al. [130] have found that sub-nanometer, ultrafine particle size and high dispersion of PtO-clusters containing 6 - 10 Pt atoms on anatase TiO2{001} nanosheets demonstrated remarkable hydrogen oxidation reaction suppression ability whereas its hydrogen evolution capacity is still comparable to that of metallic Pt cocatalyst (depicted in Fig. 33 ). DFT calculations on Pt8O8/TiO2(001) and Pt12/TiO2(001) indicate that the activation of O2/H2 to generate surface H* and O* is much more difficult on Pt-oxide compared with metallic Pt cluster on TiO2(001) surface, thus indicating a higher suppression ability relative to Pt-clusters in dissociating the evolved H2 into H+ and e− reversibly or activating O2 molecules (Fig. 34 ). Parayil et al. [205] believed that Pt0 more efficiently accepts photogenerated electrons than oxidized platinum counterparts (PtO2). However, if PtO2 and TiO2 are in close enough contact to create the heterojunction, PtO2, a p-type semiconductor, works as electron trap to facilitate the electron propagation from conduction band of TiO2 to PtO2, prolonging the lifetime of charge carriers, minimizing the electron-hole recombination and hence improving the H2 evolution activity. More importantly, such findings possibly pave the way for developing other highly-efficient heterogeneous Pt-based catalysts for clean energy and environmental applications. The existence of Au NPs on {001} facets of anatase TiO2 nanosheets exhibited 64-fold improved efficiency of solar-to-hydrogen conversion arising from the SPR-mediated electron transfer path of energetic electron generated under visible light illumination (λ >420nm) coupled with the electromagnetic near-field effect [132]. A new Fermi level equilibrium is created due to the shift of Fermi level of Au and TiO2 to more negative and more positive potentials, respectively, thereby allowing the transfer of high-energy plasmon electrons of Au NPs across an energy barrier to TiO2 conduction band [206]. The in situ ESR spectra revealed that the plasmonic electrons are shallowed-trapped on surface Ti4+, which are not paired with single electron-trapped oxygen vacancies; therefore the electrons are more readily released [206]. The nature of the support has been of vital importance in the photocatalytic H2 production activity. In this review, because of the complexity of abundant H2-evolved photocatalyst systems including transition metal oxides, mixed metal oxides, perovskites, spinels, ilmenites, nitrides, oxynitrides, sulfides, oxysulfides, only simple oxides and mixed metal oxides are mentioned. Murdoch et al. [123] found that Au NPs on TiO2 anatase are about two orders of magnitude more active than those of a similar size on rutile support due to faster rate of electron-hole recombination for rutile, thus shorter lifetimes of photoinduced charge carriers [207–209]. Numerous studies have reported that the mixture of different TiO2 polymorphs, i.e. anatase and rutile, anatase and brookite, brookite and rutile, titanate and anatase, gains advantage to the photocatalytic activity over its individual counterparts due to the formation of a large homo-junction area between two phases or the intimate contact in the interface of two phases (space charge region), efficiently promoting the charge separation [210–214]. Such a synergistic effect arising from the band alignment enhances the interfacial electron transfer rate in two aspects: (i) a passive electron sink and (ii) antenna effect. For instance, in case of the most famous commercial TiO2 (Degussa P25) photocatalyst, the charge produced on rutile are stabilized via the electron transfer to lower energy anatase lattice trapping sites and very importantly, rutile acts as an antenna to extend the photoresponse into visible wavelength (Fig. 35 a) [210]. It almost coincides with the mechanism elucidated by Scanlon et al. [212] via the combination of theory and experiment as illustrated in Fig. 35 b,c. Kandiel et al. [143] demonstrated that a mixture of brookite nanorods and anatase particles in the presence of Pt NPs exhibited much greater H2 generation rate than single anatase due to the facilitation of interfacial electron transfer across the brookite-anatase junction. Apart from TiO2, different transitional metal oxides and mixed oxides have been employed as the supports for photocatalytic H2 production, such as Cu2O, CeO2, ZnO, Fe2O3, WO3/SiO2, CeO2/TiO2, TiO2/ZrO2 [10,112,142,147,149,215,216]. Recently, He et al. [216] synthesized Au/ZnO NPs template by yellow fluorescent glutathione-Au nanoclusters/zeolitic imidazolate framework-8 NPs, as seen in Fig. 36 . The great improvement in H2 production could be ascribed to the role of Au NPs as a sink for the photoinduced electron storage and the Fermi level shift towards more negative potentials apart from the SPR effect. CeOx-TiO2 mixed oxides with different ceria contents and geometries are unravelled to be a potential candidate for water splitting due to the hierarchical heterogeneity at the interface as well as the strong interaction between CeOx and TiO2 via the electronic perturbation [110,112]. The observation on powder catalysts is well consistent with our previous surface science studies [41–43]. Moreover, the presence of Pt NPs imposed a significant reduction of CeO2 dispersed on TiO2, creating and stabilizing Ce3+ centers on the outermost surface or near the oxide–oxide interface that not only dissociated water but also acted as the hole scavengers, drastically enhanced the formation of electron/hole pairs and efficiently suppressing the surface charge recombination. Liu et al. [147] unexpectedly observed high H2 generation onto Pt/WO3/SiO2 materials due to the quantum confinement effect of highly dispersed WO3 NPs (2–4nm) and the formation of the interface W-O-Si like species (Fig. 37 ). Note that Pt/WO3 has been considered as an efficient visible-light-driven O2 evolution catalyst. SiO2 is a high cation electronegativity support and in such composite materials, silica could be regarded as a positive center for WO3 NPs, causing the distortion of adjacent WO3 structure and altering the electronic band structure via the upshift of conduction band minimum for W-O-Si species, thus meeting the thermodynamic potentials for proton production. Metallic Pt dispersed on highly ordered mesoporous TiO2-ZrO2 possessing large surface areas and pore volume, narrow pore size distributions and abundant surface Lewis acid sites, exhibited good H2 production performance due to the cooperative effect of large surface-to-volume ratio, porosity and crystallinity that induced the easier separation of electrons and holes [142]. 4 Conclusions and future outlook In this review, we have identified and highlighted important studies that provide valuable insights into the role of supported metal catalysts of Pt and Au on the catalytic production of H2 from numerous chemical conversion processes. There are many challenges to exploit the structural, electronic and chemical properties of nanostructured Pt and Au towards optimum conversion of reactants such as H2O (WGS, SAR) and oxygenates (SR) to H2. The key factors to bringing together convergent principles that are common to catalyzing these reactions is a fundamental understanding of the nature of the active state of the catalyst that facilitates H2 production and an appreciation for the mitigation of deactivation. It is clear from numerous studies that this is a product of a combination of effects with a collective contribution of size, geometric, electronic and metal-support interactions for both Pt and Au catalysts. In general, Pt is more reactive than Au, facilitating easier chemical activation processes; however, Pt is more prone to poisoning while Au remains inert due to various deactivation processes. In both materials, the role of the active state is specific to the nature of the reactants and reaction conditions, where the metallic state is more reactive than the oxide of both metals. Both Au and Pt do however exhibit structural instability through sintering under harsh reaction conditions but can be anchored onto the supports. Furthermore, the effect of the supports on these metals can be very specific to the reaction; however, it is clear that the chemistry of both metals can be tuned through the metal-support interactions. With this in mind the ability to extended H2 production further, we propose several key strategies: (1) The atomic control of catalyst geometry to optimize the presence and protection of active sites. (2) The identification of electronic and support effects so as to selectively tune the reactivity. (3) The determination of the reaction mechanism to steer appropriate pathways that can deliver products. (4) The understanding of the deactivation processes that can prevent production of H2 and formulate catalyst structure to prevent it. coredata.dc:description: The use of metal nanoparticles (NPs), including Au and Pt, supported over oxides has been pivotal, and is ever increasing in enabling catalytic reactions which target the production of hydrogen. We review here the most recent works pertaining to the fundamental understanding of the structure, morphology, growth, characterization, and intrinsic phenomenological properties of Au- and Pt-based catalysts that influence the reactivity and selectivity to target hydrogen production. We draw on surface science and theoretical methods of model and powder catalysts using high resolution imaging, spectroscopy, scattering experiments, and theoretical studies. Based on these insights we identify key aspects of studies of supported metal nanoparticle (NP) catalysts for several reactions. The main focus of this review is on the intersection of catalytic chemistry related to the water-gas shift (WGS), oxygenate steam reforming (OSR), and solar-assisted reactions (SAR).
coredata.dc:title: Au and Pt nanoparticle supported catalysts tailored for H2 production: From models to powder catalysts
